Cities: Jakarta, Surabaya, Bandung, Bekasi
Currency: Indonesian rupiah
Government: Unitary presidential constitutional republic
Literacy Rate: 93%

Japan.fact: As of 2019, Japan has an estimated population of 126,150,000.
The archipelago that makes up Japan consists of 6,852 islands.
The area of Japan covers 375,000 square kilometers.
Japan is the 11th most populous country in the world
The country of Japan is divided into a total of 47 prefectures which is divided into 8 regions.
Tokyo is the largest city in Japan.
Japan is made up of five main islands.
The country of Japan is located northwest of the Pacific Ocean.
Archaeologists state that Japan was inhabited as early as the Upper Paleolithic period.
The country of Japan has renounced its right to declare war.
Japan has the longest life expectancy in the world.
The country is also a global leader in terms of the automotive and electronic industries.
The greater Tokyo area has an approximate population of 37.4 million residents.
Japan began adopting Western styles of construction during 1868.
The National Anthem of Japan is called Kimigayo (His Imperial Majesty’s Reign).
Japan is a part of the Pacific Ring of Fire.
Japan is a member of the G7, OECD, and the United Nations.
The Japanese military ranks as the fourth most powerful in the world.
Nihon or Nippon is the Japanese name for Japan.
The age of consent in Japan is 13.
Japan Facts Infographics
Japan is one of the world’s biggest coffee consumers.
Most residents in Japan buy their breakfast in convenience stores.
Around 25 billion pairs of disposable chopsticks are used in Japan annually.
Japan’s timezone is set at GMT +9.
In 2019, Yahoo Japan announced a partnership with Line to merge into a single company.
Japan Airlines Co. is also known as Nikko.
The first Geishas were male.
The flag of Japan consists of a white background with a single red dot.
The 2011 Japan earthquake hit with a magnitude of 9.0.
NHK News is Japan's biggest broadcasting organization.
There is a special rail pass in Japan made only for foreigners.
Many companies establish mail-order businesses in Japan to ship goods to buyers.
Japan experiences several earthquakes throughout the year.
Osaka Castle is one of the most popular tourist destinations in Japan.
Kyoto was once the capital of Japan.
Naruhito has been the current emperor of Japan since May 2019.
Many wild deer roam freely around the city of Nara, Japan.
The Pearl Harbor attack was meant for Japan to take control of South East Asia.
The Ikuta Shrine in Kobe is one of the oldest Shinto shrines in all of Japan.
The legal drinking age in Japan is 20.
It is common for Japanese babies born with a Mongolian spot on their backs.
Karate is the most popular form of martial arts to come from Japan.
Noh Drama is the oldest form of theatrical drama in the world.
The world’s first novel was written on a cell phone by a Japanese author.
The world’s largest fish market is located in Tokyo.
Japan is considered the most polite country in the world.
Buddhist temples in Japan ring their bells 108 times during New Year’s Eve.
The Japanese believe that the stomach is the center of emotions.
The imperial family of Japan had an unbroken lineage for nearly 2000 years.
In Japan, green traffic lights are called blue lights.
Japan consumes around 17 million tons of fish annually.
The word ‘banzai’ directly translates to “10 thousand years”.
There are more pets in Japan than there are children.
There are over 3,000 McDonald’s restaurants in Japan as of 2018.
Japanese residents commonly practice Shinto faith.
Japan’s famous sushi dishes were once used as a method of preserving fish.
The Japanese believe that the number 4 is unlucky.
Japan annually celebrates a festival focused on fertility.
The world’s shortest escalator is located in Kawasaki, Japan.
Approximately 33% of Japan’s population is over the age of 65.
Japanese laws mandate that blowfish can only be served by a licensed professional.
Each Pokemon Store in Japan holds goods exclusive to each region of the country.

The island of Okunoshima, Japan is filled with wild rabbits.
In ancient Japan, women with white teeth were considered ugly.
Raw horse meat is considered a delicacy in Japan.
The Japanese yakuza has over 100,000 people working for them.
Baseball is the most popular sport in Japan.
Comiket is the biggest anime convention in Japan.
Around 90% of mobile phones in Japan are made to be waterproof.
Japan has a total of 13 cities with a population of over 1 million residents.
Napping at works is welcomed in Japan.
Japan sells more adult diapers than baby diapers.
Japanese anime makes up 60% of the world's animated entertainment.
During Golden Week, many people close their stores to celebrate the holiday.
People with tattoos cannot enter Japanese hot spring baths.

Japan is mostly a cash-based society.
Vending machines are a major part of modern Japanese culture.
Blowing your nose in public is considered rude in Japan.
Sumo wrestling is the national sport of Japan.
Gift-giving is an important part of Japanese culture.
Peak visiting months in Japan are typically around March to April.
Black cats in Japan are considered a good omen.
Japan considers tipping as a taboo.
Eating Kentucky Fried Chicken is a common practice during Christmas in Japan.
The Japanese do not wear their shoes in their homes.
The island of Aoshima holds a large population of cats.
Renting a person to cuddle with is common in Japan.
Japan has one of the world’s highest suicide rates.
Over 2 billion manga magazines are sold in Japan annually.
Moe culture is now one of the biggest commercialized concepts in Japan.
Trains in Japan always arrive on the dot.
Japan is also the world’s largest consumer of timber from the Amazon rainforest.
Many Japanese residents believe in legendary figures called yokai.
Japan strictly implements designated smoking areas.
Schools in Japan do not employ janitors or cleaners.
Many modern Japanese homes are fully electronically operated.
Gambling is illegal in Japan.
Japanese sake is made by fermenting rice.

Philippines.fact: The Philippines has 8 major dialects.
There are 7,641 islands in the Philippines.
After World War II in 1945, the Philippines was the first Southeast Asian country to gain independence.
At 115,831 square miles, the Philippines is the 5th largest island country.
The Philippines has had the highest discovery rate of new species within the last 10 years.
Former President Benigno Aquino III is the first Philippine President known to be a bachelor.
To date, a total of 16 Presidents took office in the Malacañang Palace.
The country got its name from King Philip II of Spain.
Covering 22,549 miles, the Philippines has the world’s 5th longest discontinuous coastline.
You can expect around 125 to 170 languages that are spoken in the Philippines.
The Philippines is the 5th-largest English speaking country in the world with over 52 million people speaking the language.
Manila is the capital of the Philippines.
The capital spans a land area of 42.88 square kilometers.
Sampaguita is the national flower of the Philippines, blooming in bundles or singles on top of woody vines.
The Philippines has almost 900 orchid species growing in all parts of the country.
By the year 2050, it’s projected that the Philippines will become the 16th biggest economy in the world.
Measuring 7.9 feet in width, 17.4 feet in length, and 6.6 feet in height, the world’s biggest shoes came from Marikina City, Philippines.
Camiguin Island in the Philippines has the world’s most number of volcanoes per square kilometer
However, Camiguin’s volcanoes have been dormant since the mid-1950s.
With a 26.8-meter diameter, the largest Christmas lantern in the world can be found in Pampanga, Philippines.
There are 3 major islands in the Philippines.
The people of the Philippines lived under Spanish rule for 333 years.
The Philippines became the first and only US colony in 1898.
Negros Island is the 4th largest island in the Philippines.
The people in the Philippines were once known as Pacific Islanders.
Before Mexico's underground river, the Philippines held the world's longest subterranean river.
The Philippine Cordilleras Rice Terraces is a Heritage Site.
The Philippines has a decade volcano.
The official language of the Philippines is Filipino.
The Philippines is the world's top supplier of nurses.
Boxing is a popular sport in the Philippines.
The Philippines has the second oldest basketball association in the world after the NBA.
The majority of the people in the Philippines are Christians.
Buko is a world-class product from the Philippines.
The Philippines is the texting capital of the world.
Jeepneys are the most common mode of transportation in the country.
Boracay is the most popular tourist destination in the Philippines.
The Philippines is prone to typhoons.
Filipinos have a reputation for being polite.
The capital city of the Philippines is one of the most populated areas in the world.
A volcanic eruption from the Philippines created a sulfuric acid haze in the world for almost 2 years.
Human trafficking is prevalent in the Philippines.
The Philippines holds the record for simultaneous breastfeeding.
The largest pearl in the world was found in Palawan, Philippines.
People in the Philippines are superstitious.
You can find skunks in the Philippines.
The national bird of the Philippines is already endangered.
The flag of the Philippines is the only one in the world that is hoisted down when it's on war.
The first karaoke machine originated from the Philippines.
Universities in the Philippines are older than Harvard.
The Philippine Trench is the third deepest trench in the world.
Christmas Season in the Philippines lasts the longest.
The Philippines was the first Asian country to have a United Nations President.
A former Filipino president was buried in ice.
Seven out of 8 giant clams in the world are in the Philippines.
The national attire of the Philippines is made from pineapple fiber.
Burying a newborn baby's placenta is a common practice in rural areas of the Philippines.
The Philippines is big in cock-fighting.
A mythical-vampire like folklore in the Philippines has been featured in CW's Supernatural.
Adobo is the national dish of the Philippines.
The National Hero of the Philippines was not explicitly proclaimed as a hero.
The first flag of the Philippines was sewn and made in Hongkong.
The longest-serving President of the Philippines served for 21 years.
Imelda Marcos left expensive collections in the Philippines.
Tarsiers can only be found in the Philippines.
Halo-halo is a popular dessert in the Philippines.
The official currency of the Philippines is the peso.
The longest bridge in the Philippines connects two islands.
The Philippines has the sweetest mango in the world.
Another national flower is in the works.
The surfing capital of the Philippines is in Siargao.
Philippine Airlines is Asia's oldest commercial airline.
The second-largest metropolitan area in the Philippines is in Cebu.
The age of consent in the Philippines is relatively lower compared to other ASEAN countries.
Rodrigo Duterte is the oldest elected president in the Philippines.
Around 40,000 Filipinos were left homeless after the strongest earthquake in the Philippines.

Singapore.fact: Singapore is a sovereign island city-state in Southeast Asia.
Singapore has a total land area of 724.2 square kilometers.
Singapore is one of the most honest countries in the world.
The least corrupted country in Asia is Singapore.
The 4th least corrupted country in the world is Singapore.
Sir Stamford Raffles founded modern Singapore in the year 1819.
Singapore is in the southern tip of Peninsular Malaysia in Southeast Asia.
The official currency of Singapore is called the Singapore dollar (SGD).
The Singaporean dollar is the 13th most traded currency in the world.
The national anthem of Singapore is Majulah Singapura.
The national hero of Singapore is Lim Bo Seng.
Lim Bo Seng became a national hero due to his resistance to the Japanese forces during World War II.
Singapore was occupied by Japan during World War II.
Singapore gained independence in the year 1963 by joining Malaysia.
From the year 1963 to 1965, Singapore is part of the 14 states of Malaysia.
The national language of Singapore is Malay.
Singapore has four official languages. In particular, those are English, Malay, Tamil, and Mandarin.
In contrast to the belief of many, Singapore is not just one island. The country is actually made up of 63 islands around it.
Selling chewing gum in Singapore is illegal. However, there is an exception for therapeutic, dental, or nicotine chewing gum, which can be purchased from a doctor or registered drug store.
Singapore is a city-state. Hence, it is an independent country that is made up of a single city. Thus, it is known to be called the “little red dot”.
Singapore Facts Infographics
Singapore is the only country in Asia with an AAA Sovereign Rating.
Singapore ranks 7th on the highest gross domestic product in the world per capita.
The service sector of Singapore contributes up to 83.5% in the GDP.
Singapore is a multi-cultural country.
Singapore has the world's second-highest homeownership rate in the world.
The government spends around 20% of its national budget on education.
The healthcare of Singapore is one of the most efficient in the world.
Singaporeans are part of the world's longest life expectancy at 84.8 years.
The Singaporean passport is one of the world's most powerful passport.
The population of Singapore grew 5 fold in just 65 years.
English is the most commonly spoken language.
Singaporeans sing its national anthem in Malay.
Zubir Said composed the national anthem, Majulah Singapura.
Buddism is the dominant religion in Singapore.
Sentosa Island is famous in Asia.
The British military used Sentosa Island as a base.
Sang Nila Utama founded Singapore, the Kingdom of Singapura.
World War II affected Singapore.
Singapore uses the most advanced military technology in South East Asia.
Singapore has a tropical climate.
Singapore has her own version of "winter".
Bukit Timah is the highest point in Singapore.
Singapore is one of the four "Asian Tigers" in Asia.
The best traits of Singapore are Dynamic, Business-Friendly, and Competitive.
Singaporeans benefit from a good employment rate.
The Government of Singapore helps needy citizens.
87% of the homeless people in Singapore are men.
Singapore is the 3rd largest foreign exchange center globally.
Singapore is the world's second-largest gambling hub.
Singapore just recently opened the casinos.
The government discourages Singapore citizens to gamble.
Most Singaporean casino players lost on its opening year.
The Marina Bay Sands casino is the world's most expensive standalone casino property.
Singapore is Asia's leading oil trading hub.
Singapore's wealth did not happen by chance.
Singapore has more tourists than local citizens.
Half a million Singaporeans benefit from the tourism industry.
Tourism in Singapore did not happen by luck or accident, it was built.
Singapore's train system is one of the world's best.
Besides the efficient train system of Singapore, taxis and buses are also very reliable.
Singapore's food diversity is one of the best reasons to love the country.
Bak Kut Teh has been around in the country even before Singapore was developed.
The Hainanese chicken rice is the national dish of Singapore.
Singaporeans enjoy a variety of sports.
Tan Howe Liang gave Singapore her first Olympic medal.
Joseph Schooling beat Michael Phelps and gave Singapore her first gold medal in the Olympics.
Kathie Lee Lee Beng finished 8th place in the Miss Universe.
Water consumption in Singapore is expected to double from 380 to 760 million gallons per day as the years go by.
Singapore currently uses 4 different solutions to water challenges.
The second solution of Singapore to the water challenges is by importation.
Singapore has an urban rainwater catchments.
Singapore also relies on reclaimed water.
The Ministry of the Environment and Water Resources created NEWater.
Singapore needs more sand for land reclamation.
The "Little Red Dot" is getting bigger.
The Singapore Kindness Movement teaches her citizens about good values.
Singaporeans plants trees annually.
The government does not encourage Singaporeans to own cars.
Singapore Flyer took more than 2 years to build.
The Singapore Flyer has 28 capsules with a capacity of 28 passengers each.
The Singapore Flyer offers a birds-eye view along with a fancy meal.
Singapore has a height limit for its buildings.
The Guoco Tower is the tallest building in Singapore.
All 18-year-old male Singaporeans are required to be a full-time national serviceman.
Full-time national servicemen are literally full-time.
The Singapore flag has a crescent moon and five stars.
Singapore's national stadium is the largest free-standing dome structure in the world.
Swan Lake is the oldest ornamental water-feature in Singapore.
Singlish made it to the Oxford dictionary.
The probiotic drink Yakult in Singapore has different flavors and its much bigger.

Changi Airport continues to blossom year after year.

The government made an anti-hippie move.

The legacy of the Ng Family in Singapore.

Singapore managed to squeeze in a 3,000-kilometer road inside the country.
The Lion is the national animal of Singapore.
Singapore is a fine city.

South Korea.fact: The name ‘Korea’ originated from ‘Goryeo,’ which means ‘high and clear.’
South Korea occupies 45% of the southern region of the Korean peninsula.
South Korea is also known as the “Land of High Mountains and Sparkling Streams” and “Land of the Morning Calm.”
South Korea covers a land area of 100,210 sq km, almost the size of Indiana state.
Over 51 million people live in South Korea.
Seoul functions as the cultural, economic, and political center and capital of South Korea.
Sejong City is the administrative capital of South Korea.
The official currency of South Korea is the Korean won.
South Korea has no national religion and constitutionally guarantees freedom of religion.
South Korea typically experiences cold, dry winters and hot, humid summers.
East coast, particularly Taegu, is the driest region while the south coast is the wettest.
The most important crop in South Korea is rice.
South Korea is known for the superior-quality ginseng that it exports.
In South Korea, a name written in red ink indicates that the person is going to die or already dead.
BCE.
Babies in South Korea are automatically 1 year old upon birth.
South Korea ties with Japan for the lowest percentage of overweight people.
Men in South Korea also use makeup with nearly 20% reported using regularly.
South Korean company Samsung produces the microchips used in Apple iPhones.
South Korea has the fastest wireless speed in the world with an average download speed of 33.5 Mbps.
South Korea Facts Infographics
Dreaming of pigs is a good omen in South Korea.
The Seoul Capital Area houses over half of the population of South Korea.
SoKor harvests over 90% of the seaweed consumed around the world.
South Korea consists of over 4,000 islands.
The Demilitarized Zone (DMZ) separates North Korea from South Korea.
The DMZ spreads up to 4 km or 2.5 miles wide.
Within the DMZ rests P’anmunjŏm, also known as the 'truce village.'
South Korea has free WiFi everywhere.
Parasite was the first South Korean film to be nominated for the Oscars.
South Korea is a mountainous country.
South Korea has 3 main rivers.
Gifting someone with shoes has a negative meaning in Korea.
South Korean mountains do not have very high elevations.
The longest river in South Korea is the Naktong River.
South Korea experiences the warmest weather in August.
Around ⅔ of South Korea used to be covered with forests.
South Korea has 9 provinces.
The Korean War was the first major military conflict between the US and the Soviet Union.
South Korea houses the first astronomical laboratory in the world.
South Korea employed the first robotic prison guards on the planet.
South Korea is home to the largest department store in the world.
Jinro Soju has been the best-selling liquor in the world for 11 consecutive years.
Hyundai KIA is the 5th largest automaker in the world and 2nd largest in Asia.
South Koreans have the highest estimated IQ in the whole world.
South Koreans appear to have links to the people of Central Asia.
South Korea’s population is homogenous.
There are 2 traditional kinds of marriage in South Korea.
The legal age in South Korea is 19.
Over 20% of the population of South Korea has Kim as their last name.
In South Korea, people who reach 60 years old must throw an extravagant party or ‘hwangap.’
In Jeju Island, it is traditional for women to go to work while the husbands stay home.

In South Korea, same-sex touching is customary among friends.
South Korea is the plastic surgery capital of the world.
South Koreans are serious about blood types.
The South Korean government has the State Council as the highest executive body.
South Korea observes a multiparty system.
It is compulsory for all South Korean males to undergo military service.
South Korea shares a Mutual Defense Treaty with the United States.
Figure skater Yuna Kim was the first Korean winner of any Olympic figure skating discipline.
Yuna Kim’s combined scores earned an entry in the Guinness World Records.
All locals speak the South Korean language.
In South Korea, the Korean script is called Hangul.
The proper word for the Korean wave is ‘Hallyu.’
‘Hanbok’ refers to the traditional dress worn in South Korea.
Both men and women used to wear hanboks.
Group blind dating is part of the culture of South Korea.
In South Korea, it is not good to leave an electric fan on overnight.
In South Korea, heated floors take the place of air heaters.
South Korea practices crime reenactment.
The number 4 is considered unlucky in South Korea.
Red is a lucky color in South Korea.
Eyelid surgery is the most common cosmetic procedure done in Korea.
In South Korea, there is a color code for taxis.
South Korea considers videogames as a proper sport.
South Koreans fear the sun.
Meals in South Korea have many components.
Koreans view leg fidgeting is bad luck.
Kimchi is the national dish of South Korea.
Kimchi has around 170 varieties.
Bibimbap is an iconic South Korean dish.
South Koreans are fond of sweet potatoes.
In South Korea, it is best to eat octopus raw.
Kimjang is a traditional kimchi practice in South Korea.
In South Korea, Valentine's Day is for men.
March 14 is White Day in South Korea.
Almost every 14th of the month in South Korea has a corresponding romantic-themed holiday.
South Korea celebrates the Harvest Moon Festival.
The Boryeong Mud Festival in South Korea draws millions of foreigners annually.
South Korea is home to numerous UNESCO World Heritage Sites.
Haesindang Park in South Korea is full of penis statues.
Jeju is the largest island in South Korea.
The national flower of South Korea is the Mugunghwa or Rose of Sharon.
The crane is a good fortune symbol in South Korea.
South Koreans have a feces obsession.
Popular music from South Korea is called 'K-pop.'
South Korean boyband BTS was the first K-pop artist to reach #1 in the US Billboard 200 chart.
Hallyu' or Korean wave has brought several South Korean personalities to the international limelight.
Koreans believe that crows are unlucky.
Eating rice cakes before an exam is good luck in South Korea.

Thailand.fact: Thailand got its name from the Thai people, the ethnic group of the central plains.
Thailand sits at the heart of Southeast Asia’s mainland.
‘Thai’ refers to the people of Thailand.
World Population Review
Thailand’s currency is the Baht (THB).
The founding of Thailand as an independent nation occurred in 1769.
Thailand’s official English name is “The Kingdom of Thailand.”
Thailand got the nickname “The Land of a Thousand Smiles” due to the culture and tourism of the country.
Thailand cities have a total of 32 sovereign ones, along with the numerous smaller towns that contribute to the country’s vast population.
The country is divided into 4 regions with distinct cultural aesthetic and geographic features.
Bangkok, Samut Prakan, Mueang Nonthaburi, and Udon Thani are Thailand’s largest cities by population.
Bangkok, Thailand’s capital city, has a population of 10,350,204.
The country celebrates its National Day on December 5.
It has the digits 66 as its dialing code.
Thai sites have .th as their prominent internet domain.
Thailand ranks 50 among the world’s largest countries and is only a bit larger than Spain.
It is the only Southeast Asian country that never experienced the colonization of a European country.
The country observes the Indochina Timezone all year-round.
The Northeast and Southwest monsoon winds mainly affect the climate of Thailand.
The waters of Thailand are home to poisonous jellyfish.
Before 1938, the old name of Thailand is ‘Siam.’
Phibun directed this change as part of an anti-Chinese campaign with the slogan ‘Thailand for the Thai.’
Thailand’s current government grew very similar to that of England.
Thailand is the 51st largest nation in the world.
The Land of a Thousand Smiles shares state boundaries with 4 countries.
Northern Thailand has Myanmar and Laos on the opposite of the border.
A large mountain range isolates Northeastern Thailand from the rest of the regions.
On the other hand, Southern Thailand is more on the Malay peninsula.
Central Thailand is the most dominant of all regions.
The capital city Bangkok used to be on stilts raised on canals or ‘khlongs.’
Thailand’s location is entirely tropical and embraces diverse ecosystems.
The seasons of Thailand only rotate between hot, cool and wet.
The Thai language also partakes in English more than you might know.
Thailand’s culture is a hodgepodge of influences.
The traditional Thai greeting has female and male variations.
Shaking hands is not so popular in the Land of a Thousand Smiles.
Regarding a monk requires a much higher wai.
Buddha is more significant in Thai culture than you think.
Stepping on money is illegal in Thailand.
Using the index finger to point at another person is not acceptable in Thai culture.
When you enter someone else’s home, step over the threshold upon entry instead of stepping on it.
Sitting with your legs stretched out in your front is frowned upon.
Thailand’s dining manners frown upon collecting each food type on a plate at the beginning of a meal.
You could express your appreciation of a meal without saying a word, the Thai way.
The country celebrates the Makha Puja festival through the February full moon.
Songkran Festival is celebrated during April, the hottest month of a Thai year.
Thailand has Muay Thai as its national sport.
The national religion of the country is Theravada Buddhism.
‘The Land of Buddhism’ is another way to describe Thailand.
High regard for Buddhism in Thailand requires tradition practices for men to follow.
Even visitors could have the opportunity to learn meditation basics in temples all over the country.
Contrary to popular belief, Buddhists are not entirely vegetarians.
Not to ruin your association of the two items, but chopsticks and Thailand do not have that kind of relationship.
Thai dishes only serve bite-size pieces of meat.
Thai laws are almost exactly the same as that of other countries except for a few interesting ones.
Thailand’s life expectancy is lower than the records of more than half the countries with available data.
Thailand banned prostitution since 1960.
Another banned thing in Thailand is logging.
The forbiddance of logging put the future of their long-tail boats at risk.
The making of the traditional long-tail boats applies inherited techniques from families and generations.
Even in the building of the boats, there is still an honor for Buddha.
Spirits also have a significant place in Thai culture.
Local beer is much safer for drinking than tap water in Thailand.
The Thai way of drinking beer is on the rocks.
A foreigner’s attempt in handling a shot of the local drink ‘moonshine’ is the locals’ amusement.
Thailand’s culture also has a unique way of ‘cheers.’
The staple in every single Thai meal is rice.
A 3-wheeled, open-air vehicle called Tuk Tuk is the traditional mode of transport in Bangkok.
Thailand is also home to peculiar animals.
The presence of whale sharks in Thai waters became a tourist attraction.
Bangkok has two universities dedicated to Buddhism.
Thailand is home to nearly 35,000 temples nationwide.
You could learn the art of massage in Thailand.
Wat Bang Phra is known for the traditional Sak Yant tattoo.
The traditional Sak Yant tattoo application makes use of a 2-foot long bamboo needle.
You have to be careful when getting a tattoo in Thailand for the possibility of offending the locals.
Taking photos of Buddha are allowed in Thailand, unlike in Japan.
Thai buildings often have spirit or ‘phi’ houses outside.
The Doi Suthep Chiang Mai temple has a staircase with over 300 steps.
Most of today’s Bangkok roads used to be floating water markets.
Not all ‘animal sanctuaries’ in the country are kind to the animals that they keep.
The largest park in Thailand is the Kaeng Krachan National Park located along the Myanmar border.
You can eat scorpion at Khao San Road.
Thailand rail services are notable for their delays.
Thailand ranks 2nd in the world’s largest rice exporters.
Bangkok holds the record for the most visited city in the world.
You can find one of the most majestic giant Buddhas in the world in the Land of Buddhism.
The list of the most visited attractions in the world includes Bangkok’s The Grand Palace.
One of the biggest marketplaces in Asia is Bangkok’s Chatuchak Weekend Market.
The first official national park built in the country is the Khao Yai National Park.
The highest and largest rapids of Central Thailand is Saraburi’s Krok E-Dok Waterfall.
The national symbol of Thailand is made up of significant items in the country’s founding and culture.
More than 300,000 elephants existed in Thailand at the onset of the 20th century.
The Thailand economy story is considered as an inspirational development success.
Make sure not to fall victim to the ‘Baht Scam,’ one of the most prevalent scams in the country.
Take note also of the Sombondee Restaurant Scam.
Thailand is the origin of the infamous term ‘Siamese twins’ due to its former name Siam.
Another Thailand-born is energy drinks.
Contrary to English, the Thai language puts the word ‘ko’ or ‘island’ before the name itself.
Leonardo Dicaprio’s movie The Beach filmed a scene in Haew Suwat Waterfall, Thailand.

Vietnam.fact: Originally, the name of the country comes in two words, ‘Viet Nam.’
The location of Vietnam is in Southeast Asia, on the east of the Indochinese Peninsula.
Vietnam covers a total area of 331,230.8 square kilometers.
The capital of Vietnam is Hanoi which is only the second-largest city by population.
As of January 16, 2020, Vietnam has a population of 96,937,812.
The largest city in Vietnam is Ho Chi Minh City.
Vietnam celebrates its National Day every 2nd of September.
Vietnamese food has three main categories respective to the primary regions of the country: north, south and central.
Life expectancy in Vietnam is 75 years.
The international dialing code for the country is +84.
Following the Indochina Time (ICT), Vietnam Standard Time is 7 hours ahead of Greenwich Mean Time (+7).
Education in Vietnam begins with 5 years of compulsory primary school, from age 6-11.
To summon children, schools use traditional gongs instead of bells.
The literacy level in Vietnam is 94%.
The currency used in the country is the Vietnamese Dong.
The largest natural cave in the world called Son Doong is located in Vietnam.
In Vietnam’s Bin Chau Hotsprings, it is hot enough to boil eggs.
Egg coffee is a delicacy, especially in Hanoi.
The size of Vietnam is around thrice larger than Tennessee and a little over Mexico.
Around 40% of Vietnamese are named Nguyen, the most common name in the country.
Vietnam Facts Infographics
Vietnam shares land borders with three other Southeast Asian countries.
Due to the location and topography of the country, the climate in Vietnam is tropical monsoon.
In Northern Vietnam, winter is severe.
Central Vietnam has typically hot and sunny summers.
Southern Vietnam is more on the hot and sunny climate.
The national economic hub in Vietnam is Ho Chi Minh City.
Vietnam’s Ha Long Bay is a UNESCO World Heritage Site.
The Fansipan mountain in Vietnam is the highest peak in the Indochina.
Vietnam’s Perfume River earned its name from the scent of the tropical flowers falling into the water every autumn.
Most of the crops in Vietnam are grown near its two main rivers.
The Hoan Kiem Lake is the locals’ favorite scenic spot.
Only the royal family of Vietnam and their eunuch servants could access the Forbidden Purple City.
The tunnels of Cu Chi dates back to the Vietnam War.
Many Vietnamese make it obligatory to visit the Reunification Palace.
It is famous for being the place where the war ended.
The first president of the country was Ho Chi Minh whose body is embalmed, on display in a mausoleum.
China invaded Vietnam four times.
World War II left Vietnam under Frend Indochinese rule in 1887.
The Vietnam War is the Second War of Indochina and was America’s longest war.
Communist North Vietnam and anti-communist Southern Vietnam fought in the war.
The Vietnam War was also regarded as ‘The War That The U.S. Lost’.
North Vietnam won the ‘Vietnam War’.
The flag of Vietnam has a golden star in the middle of a red background.
A single political party rules over Vietnam.
The national flower of Vietnam is the lotus.
Vietnamese culture evidently has Chinese origins.
Traditional Vietnamese culture upholds the core values of harmony, humanity, family, and community.
The most important social unit in Vietnam is the clan.
Naming villages after resident clans is a norm in Vietnam.
Vietnamese traditional funeral ceremony lasts up to almost two years.
The most important festival for the Vietnamese is the Tet Nguyen Dan.
Vietnamese have a festival called ‘Love Market’.
Child labor trafficking is a major problem in Vietnam.
Vietnamese people have mixed origins.
The Happy Planet Index listed Vietnam as the 5th happiest nation in the world.
Vietnam is home to 54 ethnic minority groups.
Of the ethnic minority population residing in Vietnam, 85% belong to indigenous groups.
The national language of Vietnam is called Quoc-ngu.
In the 8th century, a writing system called Chunom was developed.
Vietnam was once a Chinese province for more than a millennia.
The Vietnamese language is a reflection of the hodgepodge of racial and cultural origins that met in the country.
French is a prevailing second language among educated Vietnamese.
Vietnamese construction styles also demonstrate a variety of cultures.
The most common mode of transport in Vietnam is motorbikes.
Traditional clothing for Vietnamese women is called the ‘ao dai.’
Traditional clothing for Vietnamese men is almost identical to that of women.
Vietnam also applies the principle of yin and yang.
Vietnamese cuisine is famous for achieving the balance of the five Asian elements.
The most common Vietnamese breakfast is the pairing of baguettes and coffee.
A typical Vietnamese dinner has one to two main dishes.
Vietnam also has a reputation for its street food culture.
Rice is a staple part of meals in Vietnam.
The most famous dish in Vietnam is phở.
In Vietnam, cooking a pig would mean cooking the entire animal.
Vietnamese drink snake wine for health, vitality, and restorative purposes.
Cats and dogs are popular ingredients for dishes in Vietnam.
Vietnam upholds no official legal drinking age.
Vietnam ranks third in the largest beer consumers in Asia.
Vietnam boasts of nearly 50 national musical instruments.
Vietnam’s Quan Ho folk songs are part of the UNESCO Cultural Heritage.
Vietnamese dances developed in the Imperial Courts are complex routines requiring great skills to master.
The Vietnamese martial arts philosophy guiding the country’s martial arts practice is called ‘Viet Vo Dao’.
The traditional sport in Vietnam is the sepak takraw.
Water puppetry is a popular art form in Vietnam.
The largest exporter of cashew nuts in the world is Vietnam.
The best time to visit Vietnam is all year round.
Sometimes, travelers avoid visiting the country from September to February.
Vietnam became a well-known tourist destination starting in the 1990s.
The largest artificial sea in Southeast Asia is in Vietnam.
A major attraction called Happyland will soon open in Vietnam.
Foreigners could apply for a Temporary Residence Card for Vietnam.
The second-largest producer of coffee in the world is Vietnam.
Vietnamese believe in Tao Quan or the Three Kitchen Gods.
Vietnamese pagodas and temples have different representations in religious construction.
The largest established religion in Vietnam is Buddhism.
When visiting Buddhist pagodas, people should remove their shoes.
Although Vietnamese temples do not expect donations, they gracefully receive those given.
The second-largest religion in Vietnam is Catholicism.
Vietnam also has indigenous religions.
Vietnam demonstrated the world’s highest rate of economic growth since 2000.
